I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will provide capacity building and 
policy advice to support the introduction of market mechanisms for electricity sales and purchases 
in Pakistan based on the competitive trading bilateral contract model (CTBCM), developed under 
TA for Strengthening the Central Power Purchasing Agency.1 The introduction of competition in 
the electricity subsector will support the energy sector’s financial sustainability in the long run 
through mechanisms that will remain effective despite political changes. This TA is included in 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country operations business plan 2019-2021 for Pakistan.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Pakistan’s electricity subsector has been running under an unbundled structure since 
2002. Public generation companies (GENCOs) and independent power producers (IPPs) sell 
electricity to the subsector’s single buyer, the Central Power Purchasing Agency (Guarantee) 
Limited (CPPA-G), based on long-term power purchase agreements. The Water and Power 
Development  Authority  (WAPDA)  owns  and  operates  most  large  hydro  power  plants  and 
contributes about 30% of generated electricity annually. Transmission is handled by the 100% 
state-owned  National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC).  Ten  regional  power 
distribution companies (DISCOs) supply electricity to all types of customers. All these DISCOs 
are 100% state-owned except for K-Electric, a privatized vertically integrated electricity utility 
company in the Karachi region. The total installed generation capacity, excluding the privatized 
K-Electric system, is about 26,186 megawatts (MW), and the system peak demand in 2017 was 
25,117 MW. The K-Electric system had total installed capacity of 2,213 MW and the peak demand 
of 3,359 MW in 2017. Including K-Electric, 120 terawatt hour (TWh) of electricity was generated 
in 2017.3 
 
3.  Pakistan’s electricity subsector is suffering from a chronic shortage of cash. This is largely 
attributable  to  tariff  levels,  collections  and  system  losses  (including  both  technical  and 
commercial), which have led to the inability of DISCOs to provide required payments to CPPA-G. 
In turn, the CPPA-G only has cash for partial payment of electricity supplied by GENCOs, IPPs, 
WAPDA and some fuel suppliers. The accrued delayed payment to these entities, generally 
referred to as circular debt, was about PRs500 billion when the previous government came to 
power in 2013. With an initial clearance of PRs480 billion and subsequent efforts to limit new 
accumulation, circular debt gradually grew to about PRs700 billion by mid-2017,4 however, it 
increased rapidly during the 2018 election period, surging to more than PRs1,100 billion by 
August 2018.  
 
4.  Furthermore, while Pakistan has lacked generation capacity to meet growing demand for 
at least the past 7 years, new power generation capacity to be installed through the China–
Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) initiative will likely lead the country into capacity surplus by 
2021 (footnote 3). However, CPEC IPPs and other IPPs are all established based on long-term 
power purchasing agreements (PPAs), which means that DISCOs and end-consumers need to 
pay for contracted capacity and supply even when there isn’t enough demand for electricity supply 
or insufficient capacity. The mechanism of take-or-pay PPAs, guaranteed by the Government of

Pakistan, was necessary when there was insufficient generation capacity, and other subsector

surplus turns them into a new threat to the financial sustainability of the sector. 
 
5.  While near-term solutions to these financial issues still need to be devised by the new 
government that took office in 2018, Pakistan has envisioned as a long-term strategy the 
introduction of a market-oriented model in the electricity subsector since the early 2000s.5 
Unbundling of WAPDA, then a vertically-integrated utility, in 2002 was the first step. In 2008, the 
Central Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA) was established as a single-buyer. However, as a 
temporary measure, NTDC housed CPPA until it develops the structure and capacity to become 
an independent entity. The separation of CPPA from NTDC was delayed and happened only in 
2015 with support from ADB’s Sustainable Energy Sector Reform Program Subprogram 2.6 
 
6.  Subsequently, the predecessor of this project supported the government and CPPA-G to 
develop the concept of the market model to be adopted in Pakistan (footnote 1). The introduction 
of CTBCM will not initially create a fully competitive market. It will provide an environment for 
bilateral contracts between power producers and distribution companies. CPPA-G will develop a 
function of balancing mechanism, in which CPPA-G will determine the most efficient way to fill 
the  gap  between  contracted  supply  and  demand.  This  concept  went  through  extensive 
consultations with the government and the regulator, the National Electric Power Regulatory 
Authority (NEPRA), and it is going through a public consultation process led by NEPRA. The 
government, CPPA-G and NEPRA are working to meet the target set by the government’s 
Economic Coordination Committee to start market operations from July 2021. 
 
7.  In the long-run,7 a market model will need to evolve and lead to competitive processes of 
electricity sales and purchases. This means that the most efficient generators will be at an 
advantage and those that are not will gradually cease to exist.  Competition in the capacity market 
will also help signal excess or shortage of capacity. Competitive trading will also create a 
transparent and fair mechanism of price settlement. The establishment of such a mechanism will 
help enforce market principles regardless of political developments in the country.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA will be aligned with the following impact: efficient and liquid power market design 
developed.8 The TA will have the following outcome: competitive electricity market introduction 
started.9

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Key  competitive  market  regulations  developed.  The  CPPA-G  has 
developed a high-level market development roadmap with support from another ADB TA (footnote 
1). This roadmap will need to be updated based on revisions to the design through the public 
consultation process of the CTBCM concept and requirements of new regulations. The roadmap 
will also need to be endorsed by market participants. Among the new regulations, this TA will 
mainly focus on the updates and revisions to the commercial code, which will govern the activities 
of market participants. Along with these, the development of competitive market contracts and 
transition plans from the current long-term PPA regime to the bilateral contract model will also be 
a key element in the roadmap. The TA will prepare these drafts with CPPA-G staff so that 
knowledge of the substance and preparation of such documents will remain within the CPPA-G 
even after TA completion.  
 
10.  Output 2: Human resource capacity for implementing the new market design is 
strengthened. The CPPA-G has established Strategy and Market Development Department and 
has adequately staffed it with professionals. These staff have worked with the consultants of in a 
previous ADB TA and have built good capacity to understand and work on the design and 
implementation of competitive markets. Under detailed design various sensitivities of market 
simulation modeling to forecast market prices will be carried out, and the detailed simulation 
methods and processes will be documented for CPPA-G’s future operations to retain capacity 
after TA completion. Further, as market implementation starts, the business processes of the 
current single-buyer model will also need to be adapted to the new model. The current business 
process is well established within the CPPA-G. The revised business processes will be identified 
and documented for CPPA-G’s future operations.  
 
11.  Output  3:  Coordination  capacity  of  the  Central  Power  Purchasing  Agency 
(Guarantee) Limited improved. Coordination among subsector entities such as the regulator, 
government ministries and private investors will be one of CPPA-G’s most challenging tasks in 
implementing the CTBCM. The CPPA-G will establish an overarching Market Implementation 
Monitoring Group to be chaired by the Ministry of Energy. From market participant comments 
through the ongoing public consultation, key issues will be identified, for which separate issue 
subcommittees will have to be established. These subcommittees will help CPPA-G manage 
stakeholder coordination more efficiently and effectively. This will also include assisting the 
CPPA-G in developing standard operating procedures that includes information clusters, sources 
of information, templates of coordinating activities, methods of collecting and sharing information, 
allocation of roles and responsibilities and data institutionalization to help keep track of required 
regulatory documents and their development status.  
 
12.  Where possible, all documents and knowledge products of the TA will be produced in 
digital publication. However, some documents will require printed copies for distribution within the 
government.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which $700,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6).10 The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.  
 
14.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of: office space, equipment 
and furniture for consultants to conduct TA activities, internet access for consultants in the office, 
assignment of counterpart personnel (with sufficient dedication to the TA activities), and other 
needs that may arise during the TA period.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency, CPPA-G, is a 100% state-owned 
company  in  charge  of  electricity  payment  settlements  and  a  drive  force  of  market  model 
implementation in Pakistan. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.11 It will recruit a national individual consultant through individual consultant 
selection to support the CPPA-G in the financial analysis of the sector, as this is a supplementary 
local support that does not require the engagement of a consulting firm. Recruitment of a 
consulting firm will be use quality- and cost-based selection with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio to 
prioritize the quality of the consultants as the tasks require specialized knowledge of electricity 
market development. Any consulting position identified at a later stage will be recruited through 
individual consultant selection.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Pakistan for Developing an Electricity Market, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
